ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Optimistic Fair Exchange (OFE) of digital signatures allows two parties to exchange their signatures in a fair manner so that a third party, called the arbitrator, gets involved only when there is a dispute. Previous work on OFE considers the two parties as individuals and there is no formal study on the scenario where the two parties are two groups of users. In this paper, we formalize this new variant and call it a Group-oriented Optimistic Fair Exchange (GOFE). GOFE allows two users from two different groups to exchange signatures on behalf of their groups in a fair and anonymous manner. We formalize the notion by providing the first set of security models for GOFE, and show that it is closely related to Ambiguous OFE (AOFE) proposed by Huang et al. in Asiacrypt 2008. In particular, we propose a generic transformation which converts a GOFE to an AOFE. We also give an efficient and concrete GOFE construction and prove its security under the security models we defined. The security of the scheme relies on the decision linear assumption and strong Diffie–Hellman assumption in the random oracle model.

ce:section.ce:para: Optimistic Fair Exchange (OFE), introduced by Asokan et al. [1], is a protocol for fairly exchanging items/services between two parties say, Alice and Bob. There is an arbitrator, which is semi-trusted by Alice and Bob and gets involved only when there is any dispute, e.g. Alice attempts to cheat or simply crashes. Asokan et al. later proposed an OFE protocol for exchanging digital signatures [2]. Alice sends a partial signature to Bob, who in turn sends back his full signature. Alice then completes the protocol by sending her full signature to Bob. If everything goes well, Alice and Bob should get each other’s full signature; however, if Alice refuses or fails to respond in the third move, Bob can resort to the arbitrator for resolving the partial signature of Alice into a full one.

Although there have been quite a number of results on OFE of signatures (see Section 1.2), previous works only consider the two communicating parties as individuals. To the best of our knowledge, there is no formal study on the fair exchange between two groups of users, i.e., Alice and Bob exchange signatures on behalf of their respective groups, say G
A and G
B . Similar to the notion of group signature [3,4], each group has a group manager. After a fair exchange, no one including the arbitrator but the manager of their respective group can tell from the full signature who the actual signer is. However, this new variant of OFE requires that given a partial signature, only the arbitrator can identify which user group the signature is from. The former requirement relates to the privacy of the actual signer; while the latter relates to the fairness of the exchange. In this paper, we introduce and formalize the notion of OFE between two groups of users, and call it Group-oriented Optimistic Fair Exchange (GOFE).

As we will see later in this paper, GOFE is closely related to Ambiguous OFE (AOFE) introduced by Huang et al. [5]. The main purpose of using GOFE is to protect the privacy of the actual communicating parties. We use the following example to illustrate this. Consider two companies, A and B, that their executive boards (namely G
A and G
B , respectively) want to exchange their signatures on a contract of some sensitive business in a fair manner so that A and B should both obtain either the full copy of the signatures from each other or nothing at all. The chairman of the board is the group manager. Any board member of A (resp. B) can sign the contract on behalf of his respective company. Due to the sensitiveness of the business and to protect the privacy of the actual board member who signs the contract, GOFE can be employed. By running GOFE, a partial signature ς
A will first be generated by a board member in G
A and sent from A to B. After verifying ς
A , B sends back a full signature σ
B generated by a board member in G
B as their commitment to the contract. If σ
B is valid, A sends to B their company’s full signature σ
A (generated by the same board member in G
A ) and completes the exchange. If A does not send back the full signature, B can resort to the arbitrator for resolving ς
A into a full signature. In the process described above, when B receives ς
A from A, though it cannot tell which board member in G
A generated the partial signature, B will be convinced that ς
A was indeed generated by some board member from A and can be resolved by the arbitrator if A cheats/crashes later. In addition, in order to restrain any board member from abusing his privilege (in other words, abusing the protection of his privacy), the chairman, as the group manager, of A can find out the board member who signed the contract.

In this paper we formalize the notion of GOFE for digital signatures by giving a formal definition and a set of security models. Besides the three typical security requirements of OFE, namely, security against signers (now is security against signing groups), security against verifier (now is security against verifying groups) and security against arbitrator, we also define the user anonymity as well as the group ambiguity. Group ambiguity can be viewed as an extension of the signer ambiguity of AOFE [5], which requires that only the arbitrator can tell which group the signer is from. While specific to GOFE, user anonymity is defined as an analogy to the anonymity of group signatures.

Furthermore, as group signature, GOFE should also have an ‘ open’ function, which allows a group manager to find out the identity of the user who generated a full signature. We propose a security model called ‘ traceability’ for capturing attacks related to this opening function. We will also see that security against the arbitrator does not need to be formalized separately as it is implied by traceability.

On the construction of GOFE, one candidate is to verifiably encrypt a group signature under the arbitrator’s public key, and set the resulting encrypted signature, which is an analogy to the verifiably encrypted signature [6], as the partial signature. As far as we know, efficient group signature schemes in the literature, such as [7,8,4,9–12], all follow the paradigm below:
1.
sign a message using a user secret key to obtain σ;
2.
encrypt σ under the group public key to obtain e; and
3.
provide a non-interactive proof π showing that e contains a signature generated by a user in the group.

In the generic construction of GOFE above, σ is encrypted under the arbitrator’s public key, and the proof π needs to be adapted to show that e contains the signature of either group G
A or G
B . The problem with this method is that the arbitrator might be able to get the identity of the real signer (i.e. does not satisfy user anonymity) because σ is no longer encrypted under the group public key so that only the group manager can recover the signer’s identity. Another solution is to encrypt e under the arbitrator’s public key to obtain a new ciphertext e′, and modify the proof π to show that the ciphertext e′ contains an encryption of a signature generated by a user in either group G
A or G
B . The disadvantage is that the new proof becomes complicated, making the method inefficient.

Our concrete construction uses a different approach, which makes use of Boneh–Boyen–Shacham group signature [4] and Kiltz tag-based public key encryption [13]. Based on the intractability of decision linear problem and strong Diffie–Hellman problem, we show that the proposed GOFE scheme is secure in the random oracle model [14] under the security models we defined in this paper.

As GOFE can be viewed as the extension of AOFE in the setting of groups, we show that GOFE is backward compatible with AOFE in the sense that there exists a generic transformation which can convert a secure GOFE scheme to a secure AOFE scheme [5].

Optimistic Fair Exchange. Since the introduction, there have been a lot of works on OFE, such as [2,15–26,5,27,28]. Early works on OFE focused on the single-user setting, in which there are only one signer and one verifier, along with an arbitrator. Dodis, Lee and Yum [24] initiated the study of OFE in the multi-user setting, in which there are multiple signers and verifiers. They showed that the security of OFE in the single-user setting does not necessarily imply the security in the multi-user setting. They further proposed an OFE secure in the multi-user setting and the certified-key model, in which the adversary has to prove its knowledge of the secret key for every public key chosen by the adversary.

Huang, Yang, Wong and Susilo [26] improved Dodis et al.’s results by considering the security of OFE in a more relaxed model, called chosen-key model, in which the adversary can arbitrarily pick a public key without showing its knowledge of the corresponding secret key. They showed that the security of OFE in the certified-key model does not imply the security in the chosen-key model, and proposed new OFE protocols secure in this stronger model without random oracles.

Traditional OFE has a potential weakness in fairness. That is, after receiving Alice’s partial signature, instead of returning his full signature, Bob may turn to any other party and convince the party that the partial signature was indeed generated by Alice. Bob could get some advantage from this as he did not release any commitment, and therefore is unfair to Alice. Huang, Yang, Wong and Susilo [5] introduced the notion of Ambiguous Optimistic Fair Exchange (AOFE), which is similar to abuse-free optimistic contract signing introduced by Garay, Jakobsson and MacKenzie [15]. AOFE requires that Alice’s partial signature should be ambiguous in the sense that Bob can produce partial signatures on the same message, which looks indistinguishable from those by Alice. Although a partial signature in AOFE is ambiguous, any third party can tell from its validity that it must be generated by either Alice or Bob. In GOFE, the actual identities of the two communicating parties are hidden in their groups. Therefore, we may consider GOFE as an extension of AOFE in terms of privacy. In Section 5, we show that a GOFE can be generically transformed to an AOFE proven secure in the security models given in [5].

Anonymous signatures. There are many works on how to provide the anonymity of the signer. For example, Herranz [29] studied the levels of non-transferability (aka signer anonymity) of designated verifier signatures. Huang et al. [30] revisited strong designated verifier signatures in the identity-based setting. Bender et al. [31] discussed various levels of security of ring signatures (including signer anonymity and unforgeability). Chang et al. [32] proposed a threshold ring signature scheme in the certificateless setting.

In the next section, we give a formal definition and security models of GOFE. In Section 3 we review the number-theoretic assumptions that will be used in the security analysis of our construction. The construction of GOFE is then proposed in Section 4, which is followed by the security analysis under the security models we defined. In Section 5 we propose a generic transformation which converts a secure GOFE to a secure AOFE. The paper is concluded in Section 6.

Group-oriented Optimistic Fair Exchange (GOFE) involves two groups of users, a signing group and a verifying group, and an arbitrator, which gets involved only when there is a dispute between the two groups. Each group has a group manager, which is equipped with a public/private key pair, and is responsible for issuing secret keys to group users. Any member in a group can sign a message on behalf of the group without revealing any information about its identity to anyone except the group manager. Below we give the formal definition of GOFE.
Definition 2.1 Group-oriented Optimistic Fair Exchange

The resolution ambiguity requires that the distribution of the ‘resolved’ signatures output by the arbitrator is computationally indistinguishable from that of the ‘actual’ signatures output by the real signer. A secure GOFE scheme should also satisfy group ambiguity, user anonymity, security against signing groups, security against verifying groups and traceability, which will be defined in the following subsection.

Traceability. It requires that the group manager who holds the tracing key can trace the source of any valid signature. No one, even when colluding with the arbitrator, can come up with a signature (and a message) which either cannot be traced to a user in the group, or is traced to someone who did not ever sign the message. A GOFE scheme is ( t,

Remark 3
The signing group G
A and verifying group G
B are symmetric in the exchange, and any user in them can generate indistinguishable partial signatures on the same message using their own user secret key. Therefore, if the traceability holds for group G
A , it should also hold for group G
B .
Remark 4
Note that we do not define the security against the arbitrator, as traceability already implies it. If the arbitrator is able to forge a signature for the signing group G
A , it breaks the traceability. One may also wonder whether it is necessary to consider the unforgeability of partial signatures, i.e. only users in group G
A and G
B are able to produce valid partial signatures. Let ς be a forged partial signature output by the adversary. There are two cases: ς can be converted to a full one; or it cannot. The former case has already been covered by the definition of traceability, as aforementioned; while the latter case is implied by the security against signing groups.
Definition 2.7 Secure GOFE
A GOFE scheme is secure, if it is group ambiguous, user anonymous, secure against signing groups, secure against verifying groups and traceable.
If a GOFE scheme is provably secure in the random oracle model, the adversaries in all the games above have access to random oracles.

Relations among the properties. The security against verifying groups says that a verifying group (manager) cannot convert the signing group’s partial signature into a full one. Intuitively, if someone (in the verifying group) is able to convert the signing group’s partial signature, it can also convince others that someone in the signing group committed to the message once after receiving the partial signature. This contradicts the intuition behind the definition of group ambiguity.

If we limit the freedom of

Formally, we have the following lemma. The proof is almost the same as that in [5] except some minor modifications, so we omit it here.
Lemma 2.8
If a GOFE scheme is group ambiguous and traceable, it is also weakly secure against verifying groups.

Remark 5
The encryption of the signer’s secret key and that of its group public key are similar to the (selective-tag CCA secure) tag-based public key encryption in [13]. The two extra components K, L of the arbitration public key enable us to simulate the resolution oracle in the chosen-ciphertext style. They are necessary for the group ambiguity, because the group ambiguity is defined in the CCA manner, e.g. the distinguisher could access the resolution oracle before and after obtaining the challenge partial signature in an adaptive fashion. Note that the signer does not need to prove in the proof of knowledge about its knowledge of the discrete logarithms of S 4, S 5 w.r.t. H

They enable the game simulator to answer the adversary’s trace queries before and after giving out the challenge full signature.

Efficiency. In Table 1 we compare our GOFE with the AOFE [5] in terms of the size of the arbitrator’s public key, group/user public key, partial signature and full signature, and whether the security requires random oracles. The fourth column in the figure shows the size of a group public key in GOFE and the user public key of AOFE. In the comparison, we instantiate the strong one-time signature scheme used in their AOFE with Boneh–Boyen short signature scheme [33].

As suggested by Cheon [36], we use 220-bit prime p for 80-bit security level. If we use a pairing with embedding degree six, a partial signature of our GOFE scheme needs 10 × 221 + 24 × 220 = 7490 bits, and a full signature needs 11 × 221 + 30 × 220 = 9031 bits; while a partial signature and a full signature of AOFE in [5] need 10165 bits and 10386 bits, respectively. Though the (partial and full) signing algorithms of our GOFE scheme involve dozens of (multi-) exponentiation operations, the costs are still constant, i.e. the number of total operations are independent of the number of users in the signing group and that in the verifying group.

The group ambiguity, user anonymity and security against verifying groups of the GOFE scheme are based on the CCA security of (the variant of) Kiltz’ tag-based encryption, which in turn is based on the DLIN assumption. Security against signing groups is implied by the special soundness of the proof of knowledge 2. The traceability is guaranteed by the unforgeability of the corresponding signature, which in turn is guaranteed by the SDH assumption. We have the following theorem.
Theorem 4.1
Under the DLIN assumption and SDH assumption, the GOFE scheme proposed above is secure (

The user secret key usk = ( A,
x) = ( g 1/( γ +
x) ,
x) is essentially a Boneh–Boyen (weakly secure) signature on a random ‘message’ x. In the generation of usk, x is randomly chosen with no correlation to identity Id. This makes the weak security (i.e. existential unforgeability under weak chosen message attacks) suffice for our purpose. If we change the generation of x to x =
H( Id) for some random oracle H, the user secret key will become the adaptively secure version of Boneh–Boyen signature scheme in the random oracle model. In this way, our proposed scheme will become an identity-based [38] GOFE. Note that the arbitrator and all the group managers will be on the position of public key generator, though the arbitrator does not generate secret keys for any user.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Generic construction of AOFE from GOFE
ce:section.ce:para: As aforementioned, the difference between AOFE and GOFE is that the former focuses on the setting in which the two parties (except the arbitrator) involved are individuals, while the latter focuses on the setting in which each party (again, except the arbitrator) consists of a group of users. If we treat the whole group as a single ‘user’, then the GOFE becomes an AOFE.

Roughly speaking, the arbitrator in AOFE is the same as the one in GOFE. A user in AOFE plays the role of a group manager in GOFE. It runs Setup
Group to generate its key. Notice that the group tracing key is useless to the user, as it itself is the signer and does not need to trace the signer in AOFE. To sign a message m, the user randomly chooses a ‘member’ of its group, and asks the ‘member’ to sign m. That is, the user chooses at random an identity Id from the corresponding space, computes the associated private key usk
Id using its own (group) secret key, and uses it to sign m under the GOFE scheme. The verification part and the resolution part are the same as those in GOFE. Therefore, we can say that GOFE is backward compatible with AOFE.

Let GOFE be a GOFE. the generic construction of AOFE, denoted as AOFE, is depicted in Fig. 3 .
Theorem 5.1
If GOFE is a secure GOFE scheme (
Definition 2.7
), AOFE constructed as above is a secure AOFE (Def. 6 of
[5 ]
).

The proof of this theorem follows the definitions of the security properties naturally, so we omit it here. Using the efficient construction of GOFE presented in Section 4 to instantiate this generic transformation, we obtain an AOFE which has a shorter signature than the scheme in [5].

In this paper we introduced the notion of GOFE and gave formal security models of it. We proposed a concrete construction of GOFE, and proved its security under the models we defined. We also showed that GOFE is backward compatible with AOFE.

Since our GOFE is only proven secure in the random oracle model, and security in this model does not necessarily imply real-life security, one of our future work would be to look for a new and still efficient enough construction which can be proven secure without resorting to the random oracle heuristic. As shown in Table 1, a signature in our GOFE scheme has more than thirty group elements. Another future work could be to build a new scheme which has shorter signatures, so that the communication complexity between the two exchanging parties could be further reduced.
